BE11:17am

Jefferies with the summary.

BE11:17am

Ted warned in March that current trading was under pressure, particularly from unseasonal weather in North America and a highly promotional competitive environment globally. This has worsened, leading management to guide FY20E PBT to £50-60m, 31% to 18% below current consensus of £73m. This takes into account the positive impact of new product initiatives and planned cost efficiencies so is quite a cut. We see little support to the share price here (despite having fallen 26% in the last 3 months).
Details: Trading has significantly worsened with group sales in the 19 wks to 8 June falling 2.9% ex FX and ex the benefit of the No Ordinary Shoes acquisition.
The acquisition added c.2% and FX added c.5% to get to 3.8% reported growth but the underlying trends are very weak. Retail sales (including e-comm but ex FX and acquisition) fell 2.6% despite 5.3% average new space implying LFL sales fell c.7-8% and e-comm sales increased only 1.2% ex FX. Wholesale sales ex FX/deal -3.6%.

Tom Dalgleish What % is international?
11:18 am
BE11:18am

And Peel Hunt with a bit more context.

BE11:19am

The scale of today’s profit warning at Ted Baker will raise
eyebrows; we cut our 2020E PBT by 27% towards the bottom end of guidance. The US market has proved particularly challenging, although this has been exacerbated by womenswear range issues. While these issues have been brewing for some time, and the ranges were designed well over 12 months ago, there will be questions around founder Ray Kelvin’s departure and the wider question of how to get Ted back on point. We believe the downgrade is sufficient to make this a ‘one-time’ event for 2020FY, but management needs to show the catalyst for recovery

Soundbuy Thought the wet would drive folk into the malls..........
BE11:20am

Headline Group sales up 3.8%. This sounds passable, but drops to +1.9% on a constant currency basis and then to -2.9% normalising for the impact of last year’s acquisition, No Ordinary Shoes. Retail sales are down 1.8% (CC) and down 2.6% adjusting for the acquisition, which implies -6% LFL sales decline, including e-commerce. Reported online sales were flat, -1.8% in constant currency, which represents c26% of Retail sales.

Tom Dalgleish LFL ugly
11:20 am
BE11:20am

US challenges and range issues hit sales. The UK market has been challenging, but in line with management’s expectations, we believe. However, it is the US market performance that has proved more difficult than anticipated. Much of this reflects the structural challenges facing the US department store market coupled with unseasonable weather, although Ted has also suffered from some range issues in womenswear. We picked up on some range issues on our autumn investor visit to Bluewater last year, but this has proved to be more challenging in spring, including women’s dresses. The impact of range issues permeates into all channels and is one of the reasons for a slowdown in the online growth rate.

Snowman Ruffer 2019 review a good read on a quiet day
BE11:21am

orecast downgrades. Management has guided to a profit range for the year of £50-60m; we downgrade our PBT estimate from £70.5m to £51.5m, EPS 90.2p We also cut the dividend to retain 2x cover, albeit the shares now offer an attractive yield of c5%. We cut future year forecasts by a similar level to leave profit momentum relatively flat. Our forecasts for 2020E assume flat Retail sales, with gross margin down 120bps from our previous forecast level to facilitate clearance. Our concern is the speed of recovery; wholesale channels will remain challenging, a point likely exacerbated by Ted’s range issues and current sell through levels, meaning buyers will remain cautious into 2021. What would Ted do? We believe the range challenges have been brewing for some time and do not reflect founder Ray Kelvin’s departure, albeit management’s response will be measured against the benchmark of ‘what would Ted do?’ Sales levels do not suggest a brand in turmoil, although earnings recovery may prove protracted in our view, leaving the group vulnerable to bid threats, particularly for potential acquirers that can offer the potential of accelerating Asian distribution.

BE11:22am

And RBC ....

11:22 am
BE11:22am

We like the brand's universal appeal with a premium positioning and quality-led proposition, presenting a wide addressable market with clear brand extendibility
across international markets, noting the long-term opportunities in North America and Asia Pacific.
Recent operational performance has been negatively impacted by a combination of rising competition from the online channel, declining consumer confidence in the UK
and Europe, and transitory challenges facing the apparel industry owing to unseasonal weather in 2018.
The acquisition of No Ordinary Shoes provides 4-5% EPS enhancement from FY22 on our estimates, which helps to offset a slightly lower organic EPS outlook for the
underlying business, in our view.
Whilst valuation is compelling given share price weakness in recent months/years, for the stock to benefit from multiple expansion requires improvements in free cash
flow, which have been disappointing for a number of years (despite healthy top-line growth). We believe this is high priority for management and, given recent systems
upgrades and new logistics centres, should enable the delivery of working-capital efficiencies, in our view, although this will take a number of years.
Valuation has de-rated to 10x P/E, 7x EV/EBITDA and 1x EV/sales.

Kiwi-juice hello. a bit late but can we get an explanation for Morgan Stanley's downgrade on Unibail Rodamco Westfield? Is this another "shopping malls will die even if Westfields are very full of people"?

BE11:30am

The gist is that we're undervaluing self driving, so why doesn't Tesla just spin it out?

BE11:30am

Efforts by auto companies to focus on mobility highlight value, attract capital and retain human talent at an important time. Over the past few years, the auto industry has set a precedent for utilizing separate autonomous vehicle business units to attract and retain talent. In May 2018, GM formed GM Cruise LLC and shortly after, Ford followed its lead in July 2018, placing its in-house self-driving vehicle operations into its own legal entity, Ford Autonomous Vehicles LLC. Since these strategic moves were made, GM Cruise has attracted outside investment from the likes of Honda and Softbank, while Ford received a $1.7bn investment from Volkswagen, providing outside verification to the value of both assets.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Even outside of the Auto industry, Alphabet (covered by Brian Nowak) created a separate unit for its self-driving project, which is now Waymo, and in March TechCrunch and Reuters reported Waymo may raise outside capital at a valuation “at least several times” that of Cruise. (Waymo has not commented and we are not aware of its pursuing such a strategy.)

Omikin Hello everyone. Finally got out of a meeting.
Kiwi-juice @ BE it was published last week. A review of European REITs with downgrade of URW to €115please
BE11:31am

We believe efforts such as these (1) create a currency to attract and retain talent, (2) increase the importance of the technological mission for the “mother of all AI projects,” (3) creates the opportunity for new partnerships outside the auto industry and (4) increases the potential to bring in new capital and fund projects at potentially far more attractive multiples.While we acknowledge the higher degree of urgency needed for traditional industrial companies to form separate “tech-centric units” to attract and retain talent vs. a company like TSLA, already widely thought of as a tech platform, we believe there are potential advantages to considering the value encapsulated within Tesla in the form of hardware, software, and access to substantial amounts of driving data/miles. Many investors to whom we speak do not explicitly include Tesla’s Autonomy business in their valuation of the company, whereas we value their tech assets at $45/share.

Included in this list are autonomy, charging infrastructure, solar, stationary/grid-level storage, 3rd party vehicle battery supply, Tesla China, the NPV of regulatory credits (ZEV/GHG/Pooling), Semi and other areas with potential commercial value beyond the manufacturing of Tesla vehicles. We currently value Tesla Autonomy at $8.5bn

When we raised our price target to $120 from $97 last Friday morning, the shares most recently traded at $99.50; yesterday they closed at $168.10, a +69% move in two days (SPX +2%).

BE11:38am

As we wrote last week, “At some point, the extraordinary revenue and profit potential embedded in BYND… will be priced in” – we think this day has arrived. Our above-the-Street estimates remain unchanged and our price target is more-or-less the same (up $1 merely to reflect lower rates – we value BYND via a DCF). In other words, this downgrade is purely a valuation call.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

$168/share requires assumptions we are not yet comfortable with. For example, keeping all else equal, we could get our DCF to $168 if we assumed revenue growth rate decelerated to 35% in 2021 and then did not decelerate again until 2029. Or put more simply, we could get to $168 if we modeled $4.9B in 2029 sales, rather than the $3.5B we currently presume. Is $5B in sales in ten years out of the question? No but it’s not likely, either, in our view. Similarly, we could model the 2029 gross margin increasing to 43.3% versus the 35.5% we expect; this, too would lead to $168. But the food group’s median is only 29% – we think a ~1,500 basis point advantage is too extreme. Lastly, if we wanted to get $168 fair value, we could either lower the discount rate in our DCF to 2.5% from 6.2% or use a ~26x multiple for terminal cash flow. We could not rationalize a 2.5% discount rate in any way. 26x theoretically is justifiable – plenty of high-growth food and beverage companies trade over 20x today – but would we be okay applying 26x on all future cash flow after 2029? Not at this point.

We think a key action which would help resolve the liquidity problems at WEIF is the sale of all or a significant part of the unquoted portfolio. Any such transaction would have a significant knock-on effect to WPCT as any sales to a third party would become a validated price for the WPCT board to use in valuing the investment, assuming WPCT retains its stake. In the week's ahead, we think it is possible that we will see some sales of 'trophy assets' to demonstrate some value in the unquoted portfolio in an attempt to give the market some comfort on WPCT's valuations.

Recent de-rating lowers P/E premium back towards the 5 year average but we think there is more to go. Risks to growth are increasing due to performance challenges reinforced by Woodford exposure, and reputation risks/regulatory scrutiny are possible overhangs.

BE11:55am

Woodford issues highlight a broader challenge to the growth outlook.

Dec69 - Skeptic Cheers BE nr 7am here have to get moving.
BE11:56am

Although our assessment of direct impacts from fee waivers of Woodford fund exposure to HL

11:56 am
BE11:56am

... multi-manager products look limited [at] 1-3% of group earnings, the potential for increased regulatory scrutiny, and risk to brand perception suggests growth challenges could accelerate.

BE11:57am

However, given Woodford’s inclusion in HL’s multi-manager funds, investors may perceive increased risk for HL as well. While the FCA have previously found that ‘best buy’ lists offer value to investors with better performance and lower negotiated fees, regulatory scrutiny of Woodford might also cover HL’s exposure to Woodford funds and could impact the company's brand/reputation. Woodford impacts add to pre-existing growth momentum challenges and may highlight performance issues. While a number of structural growth drivers remain (play on the wealth gap, beneficiary of regulatory and tax changes in savings, technology strength and breadth of offering), the competitive risks to the business are growing.

BE11:58am

MOST have been cautious on Hargreaves for a while.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Numis less so.

Snowman Issue for HL & AJB going forward is how do they manage capacity - are high fund percentages a problem.. do they owe their clients a higher duty of care when group % > 10%
Patience I invest mainly in funds rather than individual equities, but I would ignore my broker's recommendations on either. For a fund invested in the right geographical area for me, trajectory of price and assets under management are all that matters.
BE11:59am

HL has been criticized for having Woodford as part of its Wealth 50 list. While the fund has underperformed, we would urge investors to view the HL list of funds in a similar manner to any portfolio. The Wealth 150, which HL has provided for its clients, has a long history of delivering value, but as with any portfolio, from time to time there will be a position that underperforms. Since inception, the Wealth 150 has outperformed the IA Sector Return by 30%, over the last decade by 12%, the past five years by 4%, by 2% over the past three years and by 1% over the year to 31/05/2019 (source: HL/Lipper IM). Relative to benchmark, HL has outperformed since inception, but has underperformed by 0.9% over the last year. Our key point is that we believe that 'Best Buy lists' are valuable for clients and that HL doesn't have a performance issue. Furthermore, we believe HL has done the right thing in passing its fees while the fund remains closed, as well as asking Woodford to suspend its own fees on its clients' behalf. The Wealth lists are constructed on a long-term biased regimented methodology that is designed to help their clients with investment decisions. We expect HL to be impacted by c.£0.40-0.45m per month while Woodford remains closed, so the financial impact is expected to be minimal in a group context. We believe HL is a structural growth story for potentially decades to come. We believe HL offers the ideal combination of rapid growth combined with a high operating margin, exceptional customer persistency, high cash conversion, low capital utilisation, low earnings risk and it holds a dominant market position.

BE11:59am

That was out mid yesterday.
